message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: You can use an Iterator to iterate through the linked list and keep track of the current item. Here's an example:

LinkedList<Item> linkedList = new LinkedList<>();
// Add items to the linked list

Iterator<Item> iterator = linkedList.iterator();
Item currentItem = null;

while (iterator.hasNext()) {
    currentItem = iterator.next();
    // Do something with the current item
}

// Now you can refer to the current item outside the loop
// currentItem will hold the last item in the linked list

<<<explanation>>>: In this code, we create an Iterator using the iterator() method of the linked list. We then use a while loop to iterate through the linked list using the hasNext() and next() methods of the Iterator. Inside the loop, we update the currentItem variable with the current item. After the loop, the currentItem variable will hold the last item in the linked list, which you can refer to in other parts of your program.
